results.content: Good practical course. Just a couple of remarks: it should highlight to use the authors electron version. I got an error in one of the classes due to be using a higher electron version. This error also highlighted one code practice that apparently should be avoided, which is to extend (subclass) electron classes.

results.content: Another great course from Brad! This was a really great introduction to the world of cross platform desktop app development using well established web dev tools (HTML, CSS, JavaScript...). I have really enjoyed following along and building the projects with Brad. In particular, I am glad that we covered React and MongoDB integration for the third project. The knowledge acquired will help us build substantial and meaningful apps in the future. Thanks Brad! Can't wait to take your next course!
results.content_html: Another great course from Brad! This was a really great introduction to the world of cross platform desktop app development using well established web dev tools (HTML, CSS, JavaScript...). I have really enjoyed following along and building the projects with Brad. In particular, I am glad that we covered React and MongoDB integration for the third project. The knowledge acquired will help us build substantial and meaningful apps in the future. Thanks Brad! Can't wait to take your next course!

Cheers.

results.content:
Good all around videos. 
There was one spot in Section 8 or 9 where he said "i will use '_id' instead of 'id' so there wont be any confusion" for a function parameter. I personally thing, that "id" makes it less confusing.  because then you can see the difference between the argument vs the object member.

Little things like this, i think, would make it more clear on who's data you are using when and where.

results.content:
It was the type of content I expected. However, I discovered mid-course that extending Electron built-in classes was not supported, and it is done a few times during the course.

Also, Q&A don't seem to be monitored by the instructor as closely as it should.

It was the type of content I expected. However, I discovered mid-course that extending Electron built-in classes was not supported, and it is done a few times during the course.

results.content: I really enjoy learning from Brad. I just wish that more checking/testing of lessons were done before releasing for consumption. I spent another hour on lesson 31 Notification Timing because of an error in lesson coding using 'runNotify(frequency)' instead of 'runNotify(alertFrequency)'. It's a minor typo but caused much spinning of wheels.

results.content: Extremely thorough class with fun to build projects -- not spending too much time on any one project.  I'm happy he tied some React into the last one.  Brad is fantastic and this is exactly the course I was looking for to dive into Electron with.
results.content_html: Extremely thorough class with fun to build projects -- not spending too much time on any one project. I'm happy he tied some React into the last one. Brad is fantastic and this is exactly the course I was looking for to dive into Electron with.

results.content:
I have followed a number of Brad's crash courses on YouTube. His content and delivery is excellent, in my opinion, and I signed up for this course immediately when he announced it. I had not used Udemy before, and I have since signed up for several of his other courses and some by others, entirely as a result of my positive experience with this course.

Compared with other courses, this one is quite short, because there is only so much to learn about Electron, at the end of the day. There is obviously a fair quantity of repetition over the three projects, but in a hands on course I think this is precisely what is needed. 

As always, Brad's delivery is down to earth and clear. Unlike some others, he doesn't come across as patronising when explaining the simple stuff, and he is aware of the range of knowledge his students will have when he covers more complex elements.

The only criticisms I have are not significant enough to detract from a well-deserved 5 star rating. However, I would have valued some comments (if not necessarily instruction) around the difference between the release builds that are generated in this project (folders with tons of content and an .exe file) and the installers that one typically experiences when using an officially developed app. For example, when downloading VS Code, you download it as an installer. On researching it, I can see that there are packagers for this purpose and that there may be complications around certification etc, but it would have made the course more complete it it was addressed, in my opinion. I also think the course would have been nicely rounded off with a summary video, covering what we did and used across the three projects and tying it all together conceptually.
results.content_html:
I have followed a number of Brad's crash courses on YouTube. His content and delivery is excellent, in my opinion, and I signed up for this course immediately when he announced it. I had not used Udemy before, and I have since signed up for several of his other courses and some by others, entirely as a result of my positive experience with this course.

Compared with other courses, this one is quite short, because there is only so much to learn about Electron, at the end of the day. There is obviously a fair quantity of repetition over the three projects, but in a hands on course I think this is precisely what is needed.

As always, Brad's delivery is down to earth and clear. Unlike some others, he doesn't come across as patronising when explaining the simple stuff, and he is aware of the range of knowledge his students will have when he covers more complex elements.

The only criticisms I have are not significant enough to detract from a well-deserved 5 star rating. However, I would have valued some comments (if not necessarily instruction) around the difference between the release builds that are generated in this project (folders with tons of content and an .exe file) and the installers that one typically experiences when using an officially developed app. For example, when downloading VS Code, you download it as an installer. On researching it, I can see that there are packagers for this purpose and that there may be complications around certification etc, but it would have made the course more complete it it was addressed, in my opinion. I also think the course would have been nicely rounded off with a summary video, covering what we did and used across the three projects and tying it all together conceptually.

results.content: Brad never fails to get stuck into projects early to just get you coding. I love this style, it really works for me when I want to quickly get up and running with a new technology. Thanks Brad, much appreciated as always :)

results.content:
This course was nice and it did teach me something as I had little experience with the topic.

I gave the course 3 stars because I was hoping to learn much more, also (and as far as I can tell this seem to be standard in Brad Traversy's courses), the teacher did not often did not go into details on what things do or why we are doing something a certain way, which is a shame, just a few more sentences here and there would really solve this point.

All in all is an average good course, if you don't know Electron at all you checking it out won't hurt but I can't tell if there are other Udemy courses which do a better job in teaching you electron (as this is the only Electron course I've taken)

results.content: Brad just has an excellent teaching style.  Have taken several of his courses and this one does not disappoint.  It is a perfect size course for those that already have intermediate web development skills and basic understanding of React and are wanting to understand how to bring electron into the mix.  Highly recommend!

results.content:
Nice course by Brad as usual. This project based teaching of Brad is awesome and I love it.

results.content:
Sorry for the low rating. But there are some things in this course that is extremely annoying.

1. Menu'and tray is not recorded so it is not possible for the viewer to see what the result is from the actions. 
2. When the electron applications are started they start off screen and have to be moved by author all the time.
3. A course about crossplatform development should show examples from all platforms not just on one.
results.content_html:
Sorry for the low rating. But there are some things in this course that is extremely annoying.

1. Menu'and tray is not recorded so it is not possible for the viewer to see what the result is from the actions.
2. When the electron applications are started they start off screen and have to be moved by author all the time.
3. A course about crossplatform development should show examples from all platforms not just on one.

results.content: Thanks a lot Brad for this amazing course. I learnt 3 electron projects in just 6 hrs and feel really good about it. Giving a 5-star is the least I can do!

results.content: Great course. You'll learn the fundamentals of electron, how to set evertything up and start building cool applications. Brad is definitely one of the best instructors, if not the best, on Udemy and youtube.
results.content_html: Great course. You'll learn the fundamentals of electron, how to set evertything up and start building cool applications. Brad is definitely one of the best instructors, if not the best, on Udemy and youtube.

results.content:
This course was great. Building the three apps hands on helps to come into the electron functionality.
The first one - ImageShrink - was basic enough to get the some of electron basics.
The SysTop (CPU-Viewer) was much deeper, as we get information from our cpu in a executable web-app. 
And with some glaour of react is the third one very near to a usable and reusable application. Also to use MongoDB as DB was a plus.
results.content_html:
This course was great. Building the three apps hands on helps to come into the electron functionality.
The first one - ImageShrink - was basic enough to get the some of electron basics.
The SysTop (CPU-Viewer) was much deeper, as we get information from our cpu in a executable web-app.
And with some glaour of react is the third one very near to a usable and reusable application. Also to use MongoDB as DB was a plus.

results.content: As always, Brad manages to explain everything in detail and in a simple manner. He is one of the best instructors I have had the pleasure to learn from!
results.content_html: As always, Brad manages to explain everything in detail and in a simple manner. He is one of the best instructors I have had the pleasure to learn from!

results.content: Very informative course. It not only gives a good practical introduction to Electron, but build several fully-featured applications with a variety of interesting technologies. For me personally, it was also a good introduction to the new functional React, and MongoDB and Mongoose.
results.content_html: Very informative course. It not only gives a good practical introduction to Electron, but build several fully-featured applications with a variety of interesting technologies. For me personally, it was also a good introduction to the new functional React, and MongoDB and Mongoose.

results.content: The course was amazing, the apps that we built look really great and they cover all the things that I wanted to learn about Electron. 5 stars and keep up the great work!
results.content_html: The course was amazing, the apps that we built look really great and they cover all the things that I wanted to learn about Electron. 5 stars and keep up the great work!

results.content:
Great until packaging the BugLogger app. Will not run on Mac OS X. 

"Uncaught Exception:
Error: Cannot find module 'electron-devtools-installer'"

If we could fix that I'd give this course 5 stars.

results.content: Fast-paced, to the point, and thorough - which is just what I expect from Brad Traversy. I am 1/3 of the way through the course and overall I am happy I purchased the course. However, there have been a few mistakes in the code. One error I had to figure out on my own (it wasn't hard) but for the others, text flashes on the screen to alert you to the problem. I would have expected the videos to be re-recorded. Otherwise I would have given a 4.5 rating.
results.content_html: Fast-paced, to the point, and thorough - which is just what I expect from Brad Traversy. I am 1/3 of the way through the course and overall I am happy I purchased the course. However, there have been a few mistakes in the code. One error I had to figure out on my own (it wasn't hard) but for the others, text flashes on the screen to alert you to the problem. I would have expected the videos to be re-recorded. Otherwise I would have given a 4.5 rating.
